Graduate Club To Reopen Soon
Needs Staff, Clean-Up and Paint
The Graduate Club will
reopen as soon as it has enough
staff members, according to
its current manager, who did not
wish to be named. Plans do not
call for barring undergraduates
from the Club.
The Grad Club closed as it
ordinarily would for the Christmas break on December 18.
During the layoff there were to
be repairs to satisfy Liquor Board
examiners and to repair damages
done by a year of operation.
However, because of shortages
of money and staff, repairs were
never made.
The manager contends that
reports about Health Code violations were more "media hype"
than reality. He said, "There are
a lot of rumors and nonsense
going around...it was the Liquor
Board that had complaints."

Reportedly the examiner who
last inspected the Club did not
like the bathroom,especially the
graffiti on the walls. He allegedly
said,"I don't want to see that
the next time I come here."
A major cleanup will apparently eliminate any other
such problems. It will be conducted by the current staff
beginning at the end of this
week with the Club reopening in
the near future.
Another problem that the
club has had is a staff shortage.
Toward the end of the semester
there were hardly enough people
to keep the Club open, and some
of them have left. The staff
declined because some graduated, and for various other reasons, such as one person moving
to Germany and another retiring
in order to finish his dissertation.

Although policy is in a state
of flux because of staff turnover,
plans currently do not include
barring undergraduates. They
call for continuing the longer
hours of the recent past.
Anyone wishing to work for
the Grad Club should contact.
either Neil Nelm in the Mathematics Department or Jerry
MacDonald in the Department
of Geography and Environmental Engineering.
The Grad Club manager
speculated that the possible
raising of the drinking age would
not seriously affect the Club.
However, he did predict that if it
happened the whole freshman
class would be left with nowhere
to go, and doubted the Club's
staff would be able to discriminate among students of different
ages.

be avoided; if not, then we must
try to keep our fear and hatred
from boiling over completely.

that all unauthorized Japanese
planes were to be shot down,
"not in a spirit of malice, but in
a friendly fashion." That is an
unrealistic goal, perhaps, but it is
worth remembering. If you
shoot an enemy soldier on the

tell yourself that you performed

gone from loyal friend to
treacherous fomentor of world
revolution, and then from nearally to implacable opponent. In

Johns Hopkins Mourns Death Of'Howdy'Myers
BY RICHARD M. MILLER
Howard (Howdy) Myers,
69, one of America's top collegiate lacrosse coaches and mentor
of this season's Blue Jay football
squad, died Tuesday morning of
heart failure while recuperating
from 'cancer surgery performed
last week.
Myers led the Hopkins grid
team to its first winning season
in six years, compiling a 54
record with a squad predominately composed of freshmen
and sophomores. He assumed
the head coaching position after
the resignation last August of
Denny Cox, who had piloted the
team since 1973.
Cox left
Hopkins to take a position in the
business community.
Myers was best known for
his coaching abilities in lacrosse,
however, especially at Hofstra
University in Hempstead, N.Y.,
where his Flying Dutchmen
received considerable acclaim en
route to seven divisional championships during his tenure as
head stick coach.
Myers began his coaching
career at the Donaldson School
in Baltimore, where he coached
football and lacrosse before
moving to St. Paul's School in
the early 1940's. At St. Paul's
Myers established one of the
most impressive scholastic sports
dynasties in the history of
Baltimore athletics. His teams
won 10 Maryland Scholastic
Association lacrosse championships, compiling an incredible
98-4 record before Myers moved
on to coach at the Brooklandville School.
In 1947 Myers began his first
tenure at Johns Hopkins, where
he quickly established himself
as one of the premier football
and lacrosse coaches in the
nation. His lacrosse teams won
three consecutive national titles,
a feat which this year's Blue Jay
stick squad may finally have an
opportunity to repeat. Myers

also turned around the Hopkins
football program, tallying a
21-10-1 record while coaching
three grid teams, including one
squad which captured the Mason-Dixon Conference championship in 1948. That year the
Blue Jay gridders also received
a bid to the Tangerine Bowl, but
the invitation was refused.
Myers headed north to
Hofstra in 1950, accepting the
position of athletic director and
head coach of the football and
lacrosse programs. Myers orchestrated 25 years of athletic
excellence at Hofstra, and served
as an instrumental force in the
phenomenal growth of lacrosse
on Long Island. His contributions to the sport of lacrosse led
to his election to the Lacrosse
Hall of Fame in 1971.
Myers retired from Hofstra
in 1975, but soon returned to the 2
coaching profession, this time as
head lacrosse coach of Hampton-Sydney College near Norfolk, Virginia. He returned to
Hopkins in 1978, serving as
assistant football coach and head
coach of the B-squad lacrosse
program. Myers, who coached
athletic director Robert Scott
earlier in his career, also added
invaluable years of experience to
the Blue Jay lacrosse program,
serving in an unofficial advisory
capacity during his two final
Springs at Homewood.
"Howdy's life was coaching," said Lee Horowitz, assistant athletic director. "When he
was in the hospital last week he
asked me to bring him some
yellow pads so he could plan a
new super offense for next
season.
"He had an intern and an
orderly standing as a guard and a
tackle so he could diagram a
play. Howdy had an extremely
innovative football mind."
Myers is survived by his
wife, Jan, son, Howard, and
daughter, Dorsey.

Graduate Club To Reopen Soon
Needs Staff, Clean-Up and Paint
The Graduate Club will
reopen as soon as it has enough
staff members, according to
its current manager, who did not
wish to be named. Plans do not
call for barring undergraduates
from the Club.
The Grad Club closed as it
ordinarily would for the Christmas break on December 18.
During the layoff there were to
be repairs to satisfy Liquor Board
examiners and to repair damages
done by a year of operation.
However, because of shortages
of money and staff, repairs were
never made.
The manager contends that
reports about Health Code violations were more "media hype"
than reality. He said, "There are
a lot of rumors and nonsense
going around...it was the Liquor
Board that had complaints."

Reportedly the examiner who
last inspected the Club did not
like the bathroom,especially the
graffiti on the walls. He allegedly
said,"I don't want to see that
the next time I come here."
A major cleanup will apparently eliminate any other
such problems. It will be conducted by the current staff
beginning at the end of this
week with the Club reopening in
the near future.
Another problem that the
club has had is a staff shortage.
Toward the end of the semester
there were hardly enough people
to keep the Club open, and some
of them have left. The staff
declined because some graduated, and for various other reasons, such as one person moving
to Germany and another retiring
in order to finish his dissertation.

Although policy is in a state
of flux because of staff turnover,
plans currently do not include
barring undergraduates. They
call for continuing the longer
hours of the recent past.
Anyone wishing to work for
the Grad Club should contact.
either Neil Nelm in the Mathematics Department or Jerry
MacDonald in the Department
of Geography and Environmental Engineering.
The Grad Club manager
speculated that the possible
raising of the drinking age would
not seriously affect the Club.
However, he did predict that if it
happened the whole freshman
class would be left with nowhere
to go, and doubted the Club's
staff would be able to discriminate among students of different
ages.

This is the third Rush I've experienced
since I've been at Hopkins and once more people
are spreading all sorts of spurious rumors regarding frat parties. For some reason beyond my
understanding, the campus is bombarded each
year at this time with vicious lies connecting the
fraternities with strippers, drinking contests,
brawls, and other equally suspect and dubious
subjects. I have found this particularly to be the
case this year, so in an effort to remove the
shroud of misinformation that has been cast
over fraternity activities, I have written a short
account of what really goes on at a typical frat
party.
Last week's party at Sigma Delta is a good
example of your run-of-the-mill frat festivity.
EA itself is rather small, as are its members. The
frat consists of seven brothers, each of whom is
known by a fraternal nickname: Grumpy,
Frumpy, Sleepy, Creepy, Jock, Doc, and Dopey.
Rush season is about the same for EA as it is for
any other greek organization: They too try to
recruit new members, throw a number of parties
and have their special initiation rites. You might
even have heard them singing their frat song,
"Heigh-Ho, Heigh-Ho" as they march pledges off
early in the morning to the caves where initiation takes place.
Anyway, getting back to the party, by the
time I arrived at EA things were already in full
swing. I grabbed a glass of the mead they
traditionally serve and began to walk around
sizing the place up. I soon saw a couple that
caught my attention. The female half of this
twosome was a childish blond whose facial
innocence was belied both by the seductive red
dress she had on, as well as the manner in which
she wore it. She was staring at her date (I
assumed) with an air of coy blankness which I
attributed at first to stupidity, but stemmed in
fact from a profound boredom with anything
not connected to either herself or money. Her
aforementioned companion was rather handsome, in a lupine sort of way. He had a carefully blown-dry mane of black hair and light
golden-brown eyes that seemed to glow when he
became enthused.
I edged nearer as imperceptibly as possible
in an effort to overhear their conversation
without appearing too conspicuous. I needn't
have worried; the two were so immersed in their
discussion that they were oblivious to all extraneous movements or persons.
"Doesn't look like too much is going to
happen here tonight," I heard him say to her.
"Why don't we leave now? I'm sure we could
think of a better place to go." Short pause. She
opened her mouth to offer a suggestion when he
interjected, a little too hurriedly to be nonchalant, "I've got it! We could go to my place.
My roommate is away for the weekend so we
won't be disturbed. I've got a great stereo
system and I just bought the Styx anthology
that was just released. I know you'll enjoy it.
What do you say?" He licked his chops and
flashed a wolfish grin at her as he waited for her

response. His eyes burned yellowly.
"Well that sounds just marvelous," she
gushed, although her effusion lacked conviction.
"But I'm simply starved right now. Why don't

Tio Pepe's? It's really a lovely palce - so quaint and the prices are quite reasonable. Afterwards
we could go dancing, wouldn't that be fun?

ripost. I figured these two contenders were so

redhead, only a few minutes after the blond had

BY RICHARD M. MILLER
Howard (Howdy) Myers,
69, one of America's top collegiate lacrosse coaches and mentor
of this season's Blue Jay football
squad, died Tuesday morning of
heart failure while recuperating
from 'cancer surgery performed
last week.
Myers led the Hopkins grid
team to its first winning season
in six years, compiling a 54
record with a squad predominately composed of freshmen
and sophomores. He assumed
the head coaching position after
the resignation last August of
Denny Cox, who had piloted the
team since 1973.
Cox left
Hopkins to take a position in the
business community.
Myers was best known for
his coaching abilities in lacrosse,
however, especially at Hofstra
University in Hempstead, N.Y.,
where his Flying Dutchmen
received considerable acclaim en
route to seven divisional championships during his tenure as
head stick coach.
Myers began his coaching
career at the Donaldson School
in Baltimore, where he coached
football and lacrosse before
moving to St. Paul's School in
the early 1940's. At St. Paul's
Myers established one of the
most impressive scholastic sports
dynasties in the history of
Baltimore athletics. His teams
won 10 Maryland Scholastic
Association lacrosse championships, compiling an incredible
98-4 record before Myers moved
on to coach at the Brooklandville School.
In 1947 Myers began his first
tenure at Johns Hopkins, where
he quickly established himself
as one of the premier football
and lacrosse coaches in the
nation. His lacrosse teams won
three consecutive national titles,
a feat which this year's Blue Jay
stick squad may finally have an
opportunity to repeat. Myers

also turned around the Hopkins
football program, tallying a
21-10-1 record while coaching
three grid teams, including one
squad which captured the Mason-Dixon Conference championship in 1948. That year the
Blue Jay gridders also received
a bid to the Tangerine Bowl, but
the invitation was refused.
Myers headed north to
Hofstra in 1950, accepting the
position of athletic director and
head coach of the football and
lacrosse programs. Myers orchestrated 25 years of athletic
excellence at Hofstra, and served
as an instrumental force in the
phenomenal growth of lacrosse
on Long Island. His contributions to the sport of lacrosse led
to his election to the Lacrosse
Hall of Fame in 1971.
Myers retired from Hofstra
in 1975, but soon returned to the 2
coaching profession, this time as
head lacrosse coach of Hampton-Sydney College near Norfolk, Virginia. He returned to
Hopkins in 1978, serving as
assistant football coach and head
coach of the B-squad lacrosse
program. Myers, who coached
athletic director Robert Scott
earlier in his career, also added
invaluable years of experience to
the Blue Jay lacrosse program,
serving in an unofficial advisory
capacity during his two final
Springs at Homewood.
"Howdy's life was coaching," said Lee Horowitz, assistant athletic director. "When he
was in the hospital last week he
asked me to bring him some
yellow pads so he could plan a
new super offense for next
season.
"He had an intern and an
orderly standing as a guard and a
tackle so he could diagram a
play. Howdy had an extremely
innovative football mind."
Myers is survived by his
wife, Jan, son, Howard, and
daughter, Dorsey.
